content.description: The slab!  Thin climbing on dime edges...good TR but no way to protect it for leading.  Maybe a highball boulder problem?
content.location: The slab on the First Street side.

content.description: The right side of the slab...lots of big holds on this one!  Not a bad way to retreat if you opt to boulder the slab.
Impress your friends by free soloing this ~5.3.
content.location: on the west/1st side, far to the left. A bit left of "Unknown 1"

content.description: Free soloing this will make you feel almost as hardcore as Alex Honnold.
content.location: on the west/1st side, far to the left

content.description: Route follows just below a crack that runs horizontal on the First Street side of the wall. Plenty of foot, and hand placements below the crack with some hands in the crack.Â
content.protection: Crash pad and there is a slight slope down to the right of the problem.
content.location: First Street side of wall, marked on photo.

content.description: Thin face and horizontal crack climbing up frictionless rock...fun climb!
content.location: Just to the right of The Alcove

content.description: Thin face climbing on hard to find edges.  It really is a question of balance (and reach!)
content.location: Piedmont side of the rock!

content.description: Face climbing just to the right of The Lord is Coming Wall.  Pretty straight forward up rock with poor friction.  Can be Top Roped from the same anchor as Stove, The Alcove and Lord is Coming.
content.location: Right side of the face that makes up the Alcove, Stove and Lord is Coming.

content.description: Fun romp up the face to the right of Stove...used to bear spraypaint that warned the lord is coming (apparently) but this gone now.
content.protection: A few nuts or better yet, just TR this...
content.location: Right of Stove

content.description: Starts near drill hole to right of 3rd class gully. Gets a little slabby at the end.
content.location: Left side of Woopee Wall's main face.

content.description: Climb the corner between "The Iron Bar" and "Contrived". Moves up and left near the top out of "The Iron Bar". Beware of the rusty metal at the top. Set up your toprope on trees above, be sure to protect the edge well.
content.location: Walk down piedmont past the area with "Stove" and "The Lord is coming" until you can see the far-right area shown in pictures. Walk up a small overgrown hill and some steep rock to get to this area. This one starts on the inside corner between "The Iron Bar" and "Contrived"

content.description: Climb the arete avoiding the namesake of the route (a rusty iron bar and wires stuck in the rock). Falling could be dangerous because of the bar. Set up your toprope on trees above, be sure to protect the edge well.
content.location: Walk down piedmont past the area with "Stove" and "The Lord is coming" until you can see the far-right area shown in pictures. Walk up a small overgrown hill and some steep rock to get to this area.

content.description: easy 5.6 climbing broken up by three ledges, maybe a 5.8 move or two if you shy away from the cracks
content.location: on piedmont side

climbs.name: I Need To Know Where This Relationship is Going

content.description: Starts to the right of "Contrived". Face climb, crimp anything you can find, and work your way straight up. Walk down piedmont past the area with "Stove" and "The Lord is coming" until you can see the far-right area shown in pictures. Walk up a small overgrown hill and some steep rock to get to this area.
content.location: Walk down piedmont past the area with "Stove" and "The Lord is coming" until you can see the far-right area shown in pictures. Walk up a small overgrown hill and some steep rock to get to this area. It starts on the face to the right of "Contrived".

content.description: Short face with some horizontal cracks. Fun boulder problem although a little tall for some.  Watch for glass at the bottom.
content.protection: A few nuts, or a pad to boulder it.
content.location: To the left of "The Alcove" on the east face of Whopee Wall off Piedmont Ave.

content.description: Fun, crimpy and balancy.  The bottom has lots of roots and a big tree near so it is most often TRed, but has been bouldered by some
content.location: Off of Piedmont Ave, the farthest route to the left before you get to the approach to "Question of Balance".  Easy downclimb exists just to the left of this route.

content.description: A pumpy flake/face climb with terrible feet to the right of "Knife Edge". Pull hard and walk yourself up to the positive part of the edge, work your way left along the roof and top out in the obvious corner. Set up your toprope on trees above, be sure to protect the edge well.
content.protection: Trees for TR, probably the only protectable trad lead in this sub-area
content.location: Walk down piedmont past the area with "Stove" and "The Lord is coming" until you can see the far-right area shown in pictures. Walk up a small overgrown hill and some steep rock to get to this area. This one starts at the obvious "D" shaped block of rock to the right of "Knife Edge".

content.description: The goal is to climb far enough past Tylers Crack in order to use it for foot placement, once above Tylers Crack traverse left. The crux is getting above Tylers Crack, once there the foot placements are plentiful.
content.protection: Crash pad and there is a slight slope down to the right of the problem.
content.location: First Street side of the wall.

content.description: Route #8 in the Urban Cragger.
content.location: Between routes "If at First - 5.6" and "The Alcove - 5.6"

content.description: The start is about 4 feet east of the crack on the 1st St side, start on the featureless bulge, scramble up the midsection and then pull through the overhang. The crux is definitely the first few moves
content.location: 1st St Side of the wall, Just left of route 14 in the Duluth Urban Cragger book.

content.description: A dark and sometimes wet crack...not a bad lead but not much to it...
content.location: Piedmont side...it's obvious

content.description: Whopee Wall is generally the first place people climb in Duluth if they only have half an hour and don't like the idea of an approach.  Literally on the side of the street, there are about 25 climbs here from 5.4 to 5.11 - including some Duluth classics.  Everything here is in the 20 to 35 foot range and could more accuately be called highball bouldering.  Watch out for the glass and bums and ignore the spray paint that says 'no climbing'.   UMD, St. Scolastica and other organizations use Whopee Wall for classes and outings and the local AMGA cert. test is held here.   Plenty of cracks on top for TR and a few lines to lead...
